questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of chronic pain in his left ear. On examination, the pain is localized around the concha and antitragus. The patient also reports occasional itching and discomfort deep inside the external ear canal. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the pain in this region?

options.label: D
options.text: Auriculotemporal nerve (Mandibular branch of Trigeminal nerve)

questions.correct_answer: C. Auricular branch of Vagus nerve (X)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Auricular branch of Vagus nerve (X)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of severe ear pain, followed by the appearance of multiple vesicles on the external ear and around the ear canal. She also complains of difficulty closing her right eye and an inability to move the right side of her face. On physical examination, she has a right-sided lower motor neuron facial palsy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, involving the geniculate ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome, involving the basal ganglion

options.label: C
options.text: Gradenigo Syndrome, involving the geniculate ganglion

options.label: D
options.text: Bell's Palsy, involving the stylomastoid foramen

questions.correct_answer: A. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, involving the geniculate ganglion
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, involving the geniculate ganglion

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with severe right ear pain and purulent otorrhea that has not improved with multiple courses of oral antibiotics. questions.explanation: Ans. C) Normal, conductive loss, sensorineural loss, mixed loss

questions.text: Reservoir sign is seen in?

A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was present. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negative .i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at

options.label: A
options.text: Translabyrinthine portion (the portion of facial nerve lying at the level of inner ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.correct_answer: C. Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: Sialolithiasis is most common in submandibular gland because.

options.label: A
options.text: Stenson’s duct travels up against the gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

questions.correct_answer: B. Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding laryngeal paralysis.

options.label: A
options.text: In unilateral vocal cord palsy, phonation is more affected than respiration

options.label: B
options.text: In bilateral vocal cord palsy, respiration is more affected than phonation

options.label: C
options.text: Arytenoidectomy is done in bilateral vocal cord palsy

options.label: D
options.text: Kashima procedure is done in unilateral vocal cord palsy

questions.correct_answer: D. Kashima procedure is done in unilateral vocal cord palsy
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In unilateral vocal cord palsy, phonation is more affected than respiration
  • • True.
  • • True.
  • • In unilateral RLN palsy , the affected vocal cord rests in a paramedian or intermediate position (due to loss of all intrinsic muscles on one side except cricothyroid). This results in a gap during phonation , leading to breathy voice (air escapes), but respiration remains unaffected as one vocal cord is mobile. Thus, phonation is more affected than breathing.
  • • In unilateral RLN palsy , the affected vocal cord rests in a paramedian or intermediate position (due to loss of all intrinsic muscles on one side except cricothyroid).
  • • unilateral RLN palsy
  • • paramedian or intermediate
  • • This results in a gap during phonation , leading to breathy voice (air escapes), but respiration remains unaffected as one vocal cord is mobile.
  • • gap during phonation
  • • breathy voice
  • • respiration remains unaffected
  • • Thus, phonation is more affected than breathing.
  • • phonation is more affected
  • • In bilateral vocal cord palsy, respiration is more affected than phonation
  • • True.
  • • True.
  • • In bilateral RLN palsy , both vocal cords lie in the median or near-median position. Though phonation may be near normal (as cords are close), the airway is severely narrowed , leading to stridor and respiratory distress . Hence, respiration is more affected than voice.
  • • In bilateral RLN palsy , both vocal cords lie in the median or near-median position.
  • • bilateral RLN palsy
  • • median
  • • Though phonation may be near normal (as cords are close), the airway is severely narrowed , leading to stridor and respiratory distress .
  • • phonation may be near normal
  • • airway is severely narrowed
  • • stridor
  • • respiratory distress
  • • Hence, respiration is more affected than voice.
  • • respiration is more affected
  • • Arytenoidectomy is done in bilateral vocal cord palsy
  • • True.
  • • True.
  • • This is one of the surgical options to widen the airway in bilateral vocal cord paralysis . It removes the arytenoid cartilage to lateralize the cord and improve airflow.
  • • This is one of the surgical options to widen the airway in bilateral vocal cord paralysis .
  • • surgical options
  • • widen the airway
  • • bilateral vocal cord paralysis
  • • It removes the arytenoid cartilage to lateralize the cord and improve airflow.
  • • Kashima procedure is a CO₂ laser posterior cordotomy done in bilateral vocal cord palsy to improve airway, not in unilateral palsy.
  • • Kashima procedure is a CO₂ laser posterior cordotomy done in bilateral vocal cord palsy to improve airway, not in unilateral palsy.
